Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Summary of Comments on Internet Influencers as a Recognized Profession

The comments reveal a diverse range of perspectives on internet influencers becoming a recognized profession, with opinions spanning from enthusiastic support to skepticism and concern.

Positive Perspectives

A significant portion of respondents view this development favorably, appreciating how influencers provide entertainment, information, and product recommendations. Many recognize it as a natural evolution of media and commerce, comparable to traditional entertainment professions but more accessible to everyday people. Several commenters value the authenticity and relatability that influencers can offer compared to traditional media figures. The ability to work from home, set one's own schedule, and potentially earn a good income is seen as particularly appealing. Some view influencers as valuable alternatives to traditional news sources, offering more diverse perspectives and cited information.

Concerns and Criticisms

However, there are notable concerns about the profession. Market saturation emerges as a recurring theme, with many feeling there are simply too many people trying to become influencers. Questions about authenticity plague the field, with several commenters perceiving influencers as fake or disingenuous. The pressure to be outrageous or follow trends to gain views is seen as problematic, potentially leading to a loss of creativity and uniqueness. Some worry about the societal impact, particularly on young people who might view it as "easy money" without understanding the work involved or having backup career plans.

Nuanced Views

Many comments reflect a balanced perspective, acknowledging both benefits and drawbacks. While not personally interested in the profession, numerous respondents respect it as a legitimate career choice for others. There's recognition that being an influencer involves real work and responsibility, particularly given their potential impact on audiences. Several commenters emphasize the importance of accountability, transparency, and authentic content creation. The comparison to celebrities of previous decades suggests this may be more of an evolution than a revolution in how society creates and consumes media content.

The overall sentiment suggests acceptance of influencers as a legitimate profession, tempered by concerns about sustainability, authenticity, and social responsibility in the digital age.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments:

  • General sentiment is mixed but leans toward accepting influencing as a legitimate profession, seen as a natural evolution of media, marketing, and entertainment.
  • Many value influencers for entertainment, product discovery, niche expertise, and more relatable, personalized recommendations than traditional advertising; some also see them supplementing or disrupting legacy news and TV.
  • Supporters highlight democratization of opportunity, flexible self-employment, entrepreneurship, and the ability for “everyday people” to build platforms and income streams.
  • A sizable group worries about oversaturation, performative or “fake” behavior, grifting, and pressure to chase trends—leading to sameness, attention-seeking stunts, and erosion of authenticity.
  • Concerns include misinformation, biased echo chambers, audiences uncritically adopting views, and an unhealthy shift in aspirations among youth who may perceive it as “easy money” compared to education or traditional careers.
  • Some see influencers as industry “movers” that reshape advertising and social narratives, while others criticize their role in promoting overconsumption and parasocial investment.
  • Several note that pandemic-era lockdowns accelerated growth and broader recognition of the field.
  • There’s broad agreement that with recognition should come responsibility: transparency around ads and sponsorships (and AI), accountability for claims, ethical standards, and media literacy for audiences.
  • A few call for creator protections—fair contracts, unions, and safety nets—given algorithmic volatility and platform dependence.
  • Net takeaway: Influencing is widely viewed as a real, impactful career path with meaningful upsides, but it needs stronger norms and guardrails to mitigate harms related to authenticity, information quality, youth expectations, and platform incentives.

[Question]

What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession?

answer.text_box: I think it is setting a bad example for today's youth. While it is entirely possible that someone can make being an Influencer their full-time job, most people don't make enough to make end's meet and end up having to work 9 to 5 jobs. Kids look up to these influencers and want to be them when they grow up and do it as a career, which is an unrealistic expectation.
